I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan to 
the Republic of Uzbekistan for the Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation Corridor 2 
(Bukhara–Miskin–Urgench–Khiva) Railway Electrification Project. The report also describes the 
proposed partial administration of a loan to be provided by the Asian Infrastructure Investment 
Bank (AIIB) for the Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation Corridor 2 (Bukhara–Miskin–
Urgench–Khiva) Railway Electrification Project, and if the Board approves the proposed loan, I, 
acting under the authority delegated to me by the Board, approve the administration of the AIIB 
loan.  
 
2.  The project will electrify 465 kilometers (km) of railway line linking the major urban centers 
of Bukhara, Miskin, Urgench, and Khiva in western Uzbekistan. This will enable the operation of 
high-speed trains with a velocity of up to 250 km per hour, vastly cutting travel time. The project 
will create an economic corridor linking the heritage-rich Khorezm region to the rest of Uzbekistan, 
support the recovery of the tourism industry from the effects of the coronavirus disease (COVID-
19), and empower women to take up roles in the railway and tourism industries. 
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
 
A.  Rationale 
 
3.  The role of railways in the development of Uzbekistan and the Khorezm region. 
Uzbekistan serves three of six Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation (CAREC) corridors, 
indicating its importance as a regional transit hub. With about 33 million people, it is the most 
populous country in Central Asia. It is doubly landlocked, requiring the crossing of at least two 
countries to reach a seaport. Its economic survival therefore hinges on good transport links. Its 
4,735 km rail network carries about 30%–40% of its total freight and 3%–4% of its total passenger 
traffic. Since 2004, Uzbekistan’s gross domestic product has grown by an average of 7% per year. 
This has contributed to strong demand for rail transport. The project mainly targets the western 
region of Khorezm. Its distance to the country's other urbanized areas is vast. Urgench, the 
regional capital, is more than 940 kilometers away from the national capital of Tashkent. This 
hinders economies of scope and scale, and keeps Khorezm as a lagging area. Khorezm’s gross 
domestic product per capita is only 56% of the national average, and 28% of Tashkent’s.1  
 
4.  Potential of Khorezm. Khorezm is rich in agricultural, industrial, and tourism assets. It is 
home to Khiva, accredited as a world heritage site by the United Nations Educational, Scientific, 
and Cultural Organization and popular with domestic and foreign visitors alike. A nationally 
coordinated effort is underway to develop the tourism industry. The tourism sector in Uzbekistan 
grew at a rate of 13.4% in 2018, before shrinking due to the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic.2 
The government’s Concept for Tourism Development for 2019–2025, approved in January 2019, 
has among its strategic priorities the expansion of transport routes and the improvement of the 
quality of transport services.3  
 
5.  Remaining challenges and required solutions. The government has continued to 
improve a combination of road, rail, and air transport, aware of their relative strengths in improving 
connectivity to and from Khorezm. Road corridors upgraded with the support of the Asian

2  World Travel & Tourism Council. 2019. Annual Research: Key Highlights Uzbekistan. London. 
3  Government of Uzbekistan. 2019. Presidential Decree No. UP-5611 “About additional measures for the accelerated

2 
Development  Bank  (ADB)  are  providing  flexible  services  to  end  users,  including  last-mile 
connectivity. Air transport, served mainly from Urgench airport, caters to passengers with the 
highest time sensitivity, although their numbers remain low. Rail transport serves to move heavy 
and bulky goods over long distances, as well as serving time-sensitive passengers at mass. 
Accordingly, the government completed a new, 465 km railway line linking Bukhara, Miskin, 
Urgench, and Khiva in December 2017. However, passenger operations still rely on diesel traction 
and require a journey of 5.2 hours. Similarly, freight travel between Bukhara and Urgench takes 
13 hours. For Khorezm to gain attractiveness as a tourism and business destination, travel times 
need to be reduced.  
 
6.  Countering the impact of COVID-19. The project will help Khorezm bounce back 
economically from the impacts of COVID-19. Railways have proven to be the most reliable mode 
for freight transport during the pandemic, while truck traffic decreased. Passenger trains remained 
a safe means of transport, thanks to the physical distancing and hygiene measures employed by 
the public railway company, O’zbekiston Temir Yo’llari (UTY). This contrasts with microbuses and 
other forms of public transport where space is too limited to ensure adequate distancing. The 
project’s construction work is expected to start in 2022, when COVID-19 is likely to have subsided 
and  be  more  manageable.  To  deal  with  COVID-19  risks  during  project  implementation, 
contractors will have to develop and implement a COVID-19 health and safety management plan 
and an emergency response plan as part of their site-specific environmental management plans. 
 
7.  Envisaged benefits to Khorezm. The project will electrify and modernize the railway line 
between Bukhara and Khiva, extending the electrified, high-speed line already in existence 
between Tashkent and Bukhara. High-speed trains that run at up to 250km per hour will cut travel 
time between Bukhara and Khiva to 3 hours, and the entire journey from Tashkent to Khiva will 
be made possible in 7 hours, well within a day’s journey. These improvements will have several 
beneficial impacts on agriculture, industry, and tourism. For one, higher-value agricultural produce 
can be exported faster and farther, and in refrigerated wagons. Second, tourist flows to Khorezm 
will increase, leading to sustainable revenue and better employment opportunities, especially for 
women. Finally, the population of Khorezm will have better access to jobs, markets, and health 
care and education facilities in the region or other parts of the country.  
 
8.  Links to the government strategy. Transport infrastructure is recognized as a key 
growth driver in the government’s Development Strategy for 2017–2021, apt to promote economic 
development and liberalization, and support the development of the social sectors.4 The strategy 
specifically mentions the importance of improving transport services, raising passenger safety, 
and reducing harmful emissions. The project will assist the switch from diesel traction to electricity, 
and the shift to a clean and low-carbon mode of transport. It will help Uzbekistan meet its 
commitment to the Paris Agreement, as communicated in its intended nationally determined 
contributions, which highlight the need for "efficient energy resource use for transport."5 
 
9.  Links to regional strategies. The project railway is on CAREC Corridor 2 (Europe–
Mediterranean–East Asia) and CAREC Designated Rail Corridor 202, which serves the vital East–
West trade corridor linking the People’s Republic of China via Central Asia, to Europe. The project 
improves Uzbekistan’s connectivity and trade with neighboring countries, and markets beyond, 
by expanding the frequency and quality of train services. The project railway is expected to carry 
6 million tons of international freight per year by 2030. The project will boost Uzbekistan’s role as

a regional transit hub (para. 3) and support the implementation of CAREC 2030, particularly 
Operational Clusters 2 and 3,6 the CAREC Transport Strategy 2030,7 the CAREC Railway 
Strategy 2030,8 and the CAREC Tourism Strategy.9 By attracting cofinancing from AIIB, the 
project also strengthens financing partnerships to jointly improve regional connectivity.  
 
10.  Consistency with the strategy of ADB. The project is consistent with ADB’s Strategy 
2030, particularly its operational priorities of (i) tackling climate change, building climate and 
disaster  resilience  and  ensuring  environmental  sustainability;  and  (ii)  fostering  regional 
cooperation and integration.10 The project is consistent with ADB’s country partnership strategy, 
2019–2023 for Uzbekistan, which calls for the modernization of railway infrastructure, as well as 
promoting increased access to tourism destinations. 11 The project is included in ADB’s country 
operations business plan, 2021–2023 for Uzbekistan.12 
 
11.  Supporting ongoing reforms in the railway subsector. UTY is a financially robust 
organization, able to carry all operation and maintenance costs, and most capital works. However, 
to ensure further growth of a low-carbon, sustainable mode of transport, and to enhance the 
competitiveness of rail corridors through Uzbekistan, UTY needs to improve the attractiveness of 
its services to clients. ADB is therefore supporting the UTY-led initiative to develop and implement 
a long-term development strategy.13 The strategy’s main directions are the improvement of 
operational efficiency, digitization to enhance customer experience, and the revision of UTY’s 
corporate structure. While infrastructure improvements will continue to require public investments, 
these new thrusts may lead to opportunities for closer collaboration with and more participation 
of the private sector in railway transport operations. The project contributes by pushing the 
boundaries of technical innovation and reinforcing the capacity of UTY staff. 
 
B.  Project Description 
 
12.  The project is aligned with the following impact: sustainable regional trade and economic 
activity promoted along CAREC Corridor 2 (footnotes 6, 7, and 9). The project will have the 
following outcome: railway services for freight and passengers in western Uzbekistan improved.14 
 
13.  Output  1:  Railway  infrastructure  along  and  adjacent  to  the  Bukhara–Miskin–
Urgench–Khiva line upgraded. The project will help electrify 465 km of railway track, through (i) 
construction of 8 traction substations; (ii) construction of 7 sectioning posts; (iii) supply and 
installation  of  catenary  systems;  (iv)  supply  and  installation  of  signaling,  telecoms,  and 
supervisory control and data acquisition systems; (v) construction of external power supply; (vi) 
purchase of maintenance equipment and machinery; and (vii) procurement of specialized wires. 
In  addition,  minor  upgrades  will  be  made  to  electrification  infrastructure  on  adjacent  lines 
extending from Bukhara to Tashkent, and from Samarkand to the border with Afghanistan.15 The

output will cover the training of UTY staff, including women staff on operations and maintenance, 
and training of female students of technology and vocational education and training (TVET), 
including those in programs related to, or specifically in science, technology, engineering, and 
math (STEM) programs. The technical training program will be developed based on the results of 
the assessment of STEM programs, TVET curricula, and courses relevant to railway technology 
of major universities, colleges, and TVET institutions.  
 
14.  Output  2:  Tourism-led  economic  corridor  Bukhara–Miskin–Urgench–Khiva 
developed. The railway corridor will be transformed into a tourism-led, economic corridor through 
(i) support to municipalities along the railway corridor for sound urban development around 
stations which will include access and safety features for the elderly, women, children, and the 
mobility impaired; (ii) support to the same municipalities to develop a sustainable tourism industry; 
(iii)  marketing  of  railways  as  part  of  wider  efforts  of  Uzbekistan  to  attract  tourists;  (iv) 
implementation of an electronic ticketing system to allow tourists and domestic passengers easier 
means of booking tickets, with provision for discounts and priority seats for the elderly, pregnant 
women, children, and the mobility impaired; (v) strengthening women’s participation in economic 
activities related to tourism, including the operation of tourist information centers, employment at 
tourism facilities, and sale of local crafts; and (vi) training of women in hospitality and tourism 
management. 
 
15.  With the project, annual passenger traffic on the Bukhara to Khiva line is expected to 
increase from 280,000 passengers per year in 2021 to 1,080,000 passengers by 2026. Freight 
will reach a total of 11.8 million tons per year by 2026. 
 
C.  Value Added by ADB  
 
16.  ADB’s support has ensured the adoption of international technical expertise. The technical 
specifications for the signaling and telecommunication systems were improved with transaction 
technical assistance (TA) to meet international standards and to utilize state-of-the-art technology, 
reflecting lessons from past involvements in electrification and high-speed railway infrastructure.16 
ADB introduced measures into the project to ensure the resilience of the upgraded line to 
disasters triggered by natural hazards and climate change, and to minimize the environmental 
impact of the external power supply.17 ADB helped to design measures to support the economic 
recovery and further growth of the Khorezm region (para. 14), with strong gender features 
supported by the TA (para. 24). The project will have synergies with other ongoing and upcoming 
ADB-supported  projects  in  Uzbekistan.  For  example,  the  proposed  Integrated  Urban 
Development Project will further support the city of Khiva (among others) to build inclusive urban 
and tourism infrastructure and services. ADB has taken the lead in coordinating investments in 
the railway subsector through the CAREC program (para. 9), and the project will supplement the 
work done by other development partners in modernizing railway operations in Uzbekistan.18 
 
D.  Summary Cost Estimates and Financing Plan

18.  The government has requested a regular loan of $162,000,000 from ADB’s ordinary 
capital resources to help finance the project. The loan will have a 25-year term, including a grace 
period of 5 years; an annual interest rate determined in accordance with ADB’s London interbank 
offered rate (LIBOR)-based lending facility;20 a commitment charge of 0.15% per year; and such 
other terms and conditions set forth in the draft loan and project agreements. Based on the 
straight-line method, the average maturity is 15.25 years, and the maturity premium payable to 
ADB is 0.10% per year.  
 
19.  The government has also requested a loan not exceeding $108,000,000 from AIIB to help 
finance the project. The AIIB loan is expected to have a 25-year term, including a grace period of 
5 years; an annual interest rate determined in accordance with the LIBOR-based lending facility;21 
a commitment charge of 0.25% per year, a front-end fee of 0.25%; and such other terms and 
conditions to be set forth in the draft AIIB loan and project agreements. ADB will partially 
administer the AIIB loan for environment and social services, financial management services, 
procurement services, investigative services and disbursement services in accordance with ADB 
policies and procedures. 
 
20.  The  summary  financing  plan  is  in  Table  2.  ADB  and  AIIB  will  jointly  finance  the 
expenditures  in  relation  to  the  packages  listed  in  Table  3.  The  AIIB  loan  will  be  partially 
administered by ADB on an untied, joint, and pro-rata basis, with ADB financing 60% of eligible 
amounts and AIIB 40% of eligible amounts. The government will relend the proceeds of the ADB 
loan to UTY with applicable interest and a term of 25 years including a grace period of 5 years. 
The government and UTY will finance local expenditures, which will cover land acquisition and 
resettlement, taxes and duties, and financing charges during implementation.

21.  Climate mitigation is estimated to cost $438.95 million and climate adaptation is estimated 
to cost $6.70 million. ADB will finance 36.0% of mitigation costs and 60.0% of adaptation costs. 
Details are in the climate change assessment (footnote 17). Mitigation costs comprise railway 
electrification which will promote a shift to lower-carbon transport. Adaptation costs include the 
climate-resilient wires for the catenary system, and specialized machinery for clearing sand and 
monitoring track conditions. Annual reductions in greenhouse gas emissions are expected at 
81,000 tons.

IV.  DUE DILIGENCE 
 
A.  Technical 
 
25.  Optimization of design. The technical parameters of the project were prepared by UTY 
and government design institutes. The transaction TA consultants reviewed the design and 
recommended improvements, especially to ensure the safety of high-speed train operations and 
optimize the design and routing of the external power supply system.  
 
26.  Climate-resilient design. Thorough considerations were made to ensure the resilience 
of the project to climate change. A special kind of cement will be used to manufacture foundations 
for the catenary system. Specialized cables resistant to corrosion from sand and salt will be used. 
A sand-clearing machine will be brought in to avoid sand accumulation, rail and wheel abrasion, 
sensor or signal losses, drainage issues, and early corrosion of track superstructures. Equipment 
will also be procured to periodically check track conditions. 
 
B.  Economic and Financial Viability 
 
27.  Economic viability. The economic analysis of the project was conducted in accordance 
with ADB’s guidelines by comparing the incremental costs of the project with the incremental 
benefits in with-project and without-project scenarios.23 The main economic benefits of the project 
are savings in travel time and vehicle operating costs for passenger and freight traffic, reductions 
in carbon dioxide emissions, energy cost savings, and net economic development from increased 
tourism.  The  economic  impact  of  COVID-19  is  reflected  in  the  projections.  The  project  is 
economically viable, with an economic internal rate of return of 15.1%. The project remains viable 
against (i) a 10% reduction in projected benefits, (ii) a 10% increase in costs, (iii) a combined 10% 
reduction of project benefits and 10% increase in costs, (iv) a 1-year delay in completion, and 
(v) the exclusion of tourism-induced benefits. The project will also improve the conditions for more 
trade with neighboring countries, especially Kazakhstan and Afghanistan.  
 
28.  Financial viability. The project will generate revenue, and its financial viability was 
assessed in accordance with ADB’s guidelines by comparing incremental costs and revenues in 
with-project and without-project scenarios.24 The project will increase revenues, mainly from 
freight traffic that currently provides about 88.0% of UTY’s total revenues. It will also reduce 
operations and maintenance costs of locomotives. The financial internal rate of return is 4.9%, 
and exceeds the calculated weighted average cost of capital of 2.9%. The project remains 
financially viable against (i) a 10% increase in costs, (ii) a 10% decrease in revenues, (iii) a 10% 
increase in costs and 10% decrease in revenues, and (iv) a 1-year delay in completion. 
 
C.  Sustainability 
 
29.  Financial  and  institutional  sustainability  of  the  railway  operator.  UTY  remains 
profitable thanks to its robust freight revenues. However, the operating income ratio decreased 
from 0.33 in 2017 to 0.14 in 2019, mainly because of the poor financial performance of its non-
core businesses, especially coal production. The government decreed that coal production be 
taken out of UTY’s business portfolio, and is also removing other non-core operations. With these 
measures, the operating income ratio is expected to increase to 0.18 by 2030. The long-term 
debt–equity ratio is forecast to fall from 3.7 in 2020 to 1.2 by 2030, while the debt service coverage

ratio is forecast to increase from 2.0 in 2020 to 3.2 by 2030. Overall, UTY maintains the financial 
capacity to implement the project, fund its contribution to the project costs, repay the loan, and 
make the required payments on its existing debt. To ensure the future financial health of UTY, the 
loan includes covenants (i) on the operating income ratio of UTY, which shall be maintained above 
0.1 from 2021 onward; and (ii) for the government to pass an official decree to remove other non-
core businesses from UTY and to avoid adding such businesses to UTY in the future.  
 
30.  Debt sustainability of Uzbekistan. Based on the latest analysis by the International 
Monetary Fund and the World Bank, Uzbekistan’s public and publicly guaranteed external debt 
remains at about 40% of gross domestic product over the medium term. This is far below the debt 
stress threshold of 70%, and the project will not impair debt sustainability. The government has 
pursued a prudent debt policy with low public and external debt, and with mechanisms to control 
annual borrowing, while significant official reserves provide a buffer against potential distress.25  
 
D.  Governance 
 
31.  Financial management. A financial management assessment confirmed that UTY has 
the capacity to implement the project in compliance with ADB requirements. UTY has a good 
record in making disbursements based on ADB requirements. It generally has a record of 
satisfactory submission of audited financial statements, although some delays were observed.26 
The overall pre-mitigated financial management risk is substantial. Risks exist in the management 
of foreign exchange risks, non-core businesses, compliance with international financial reporting 
standards, timeliness and accuracy of monitoring and reporting, and integration of accounting and 
reporting within UTY. Staff turnover in the PIU-ET was seen in 2021 but has been addressed with 
the provision of training. UTY shall, among other tasks, (i) carefully monitor its foreign currency 
reserves and develop measures to hedge against currency fluctuations, (ii) remove non-core 
businesses, (iii) attend additional training organized by ADB, (iv) move to multiyear contracts for 
auditors and conduct midyear interim audit missions to reduce delays in the preparation of 
financial statements, (v) engage external consultants and a valuation company to address the 
qualified audit opinions, and (vi) accelerate the integration of the accounting system. Details of 
risks and key mitigating measures are in the PAM (footnote 19). 
 
32.  Procurement. A project procurement risk assessment confirmed the procurement risk as 
moderate. It identified some capacity issues in the PIU-ET, leading to delays in the preparation of 
bidding documents, and the conduct of bidding and bid evaluation. ADB staff and transaction TA 
consultants provided training to the PIU-ET on ADB’s Procurement Policy and Regulations and 
are assisting it in advance contracting. After the project becomes effective, the engineering and 
works supervision consultants will assist the contract management. All procurement packages to 
be financed by ADB will be cofinanced by AIIB. Each package is divided into lots to give small 
contractors a chance to bid, and for large contractors to bid for all the contracts in each package. 
At the same time, this reduces the transactional costs of conducting multiple tenders. 
 
33.  Integrity  and  anticorruption.  Uzbekistan  has  made  large  strides  in  improving 
governance by strengthening the rule of law and anticorruption measures.27 It set up a new Anti-
Corruption Agency in 2020 to guide and coordinate anticorruption efforts. ADB conducted integrity

E.  Poverty, Social, and Gender 
 
34.  The primary beneficiaries will be local passengers, providers of tourism services, freight 
transporters, and agro-industrial producers. The project will improve access for the elderly, 
women, children, and people with mobility impairments to railway transport, with safety features 
and facilities in trains and at modernized stations.  
 
35.  Gender segregation undermines the empowerment of women in Uzbekistan. Women 
make up only 8.5% of workers employed in transportation and storage. The project is classified 
effective gender mainstreaming and will boost women’s participation in the railway and tourism 
industries. First, women staff of UTY will be empowered through technical training in operation 
and maintenance of high-speed railway lines. Second, women staff working at railway stations 
will undergo training in tourism promotion, marketing, and public health. Third, employment 
opportunities in railway transport will be boosted for female STEM students, who will be given 
specialized training on railway operations and technology. Fourth, to increase employment and 
income generation opportunities for women in communities, the project will support training on 
hospitality, tourism management, and tourism-related enterprises. Finally, the project will develop 
guidelines  on  sound  urban  development  around  stations  that  will  help  enhance  the  travel 
experience of women, the elderly, children, and people with mobility impairments. 
 
F.  Safeguards 
 
36.  In compliance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009), the project’s safeguard 
categories are as follows.29 
 
37.  Environment (category B). The initial environmental examination report was prepared in 
compliance with the Safeguard Policy Statement.30 It includes two environmental management 
plans (EMPs) for the (i) construction of the catenary system and the traction substations, and the 
installation  of  signaling,  telecommunication,  and  supervisory  control  and  data  acquisition 
systems; and (ii) construction of the external power supply. Potential impacts include dust or 
vehicular emissions, noise and waste generation, occupational and community health and safety 
risks. These can be readily mitigated by implementing the EMPs. As part of the EMPs, contractors 
will have to prepare and execute a COVID-19 health and safety management plan and an 
emergency response plan to manage COVID-19 risks to workers and local communities. 
 
38.  Since the wider surroundings of the project site feature some key biodiversity areas 
(KBAs),31 a biodiversity assessment and a critical habitat assessment were conducted. According

39.  Involuntary resettlement (category A). The eight traction substations to be built will 
impact 28.09 hectares (ha) of land—18.91 ha of agricultural cultivated land and 9.18 ha of reserve

of whom are severely affected. Two draft land acquisition and resettlement plans (LARPs); and 
one social due diligence report (SDDR) were prepared based on desk surveys and site visits, and 
have been disclosed on ADB’s website. Detailed measurement surveys and census of affected 
land users have not yet been conducted. Public information booklets were distributed to inform 
affected people of the key parameters of the project. UTY staff, along with khokimyat and mahalla 
representatives, provided information to affected people and answered their questions. The 
LARPs and SDDR will be updated based on the detailed design to be prepared by the plant 
contractor and following the conduct of detailed measurement surveys, census, and follow-up 
consultations; with support from the engineering and works supervision consultants. UTY’s 
dedicated safeguards specialist will supervise the implementation of the two LARPs. The LARPs 
will be subjected to both internal and external monitoring. The start of civil works will be conditional 
on the full implementation of the LARPs, as verified by an external monitor. Semi-annual social 
monitoring reports will be prepared throughout the project implementation. Updated LARPs and 
monitoring reports will be disclosed online and locally to the affected persons. 
 
40.  Grievance Redress Mechanism. A two-level grievance redress mechanism (GRM) is in 
place, involving (i) the nearest railway station, and (ii) UTY’s secretariat in Tashkent. As a third 
channel, aggrieved persons can approach any competent court at any stage of the complaint. 
UTY will ensure that grievances and complaints on any aspect of land acquisition, compensation, 
resettlement, and environmental impacts are addressed in a timely and satisfactory manner 
through the GRM. UTY, with the support of the engineering and works supervision consultants, 
will ensure that meaningful consultations are carried out with the affected persons throughout the 
project cycle with particular attention to the needs of vulnerable and disadvantaged groups. 
 
41.  Indigenous peoples (category C). The country in general and the project area in 
particular do not have communities of indigenous peoples as defined in ADB’s Safeguard Policy 
Statement for operational purposes. No further action will be required.

43.  The government and UTY have assured ADB that the implementation of the project shall 
conform to all applicable ADB requirements, including those concerning anticorruption measures, 
safeguards, gender, procurement, consulting services, financial management, and disbursement, 
as described in detail in the PAM and loan documents.

which  are  set  forth  in  the  draft  loan  and  project  agreements,  including  (i)  conditions  to

duly executed and are effective, and (ii) a disbursement condition requiring a subsidiary loan 
agreement between the borrower and UTY to be duly executed and effective in connection with 
the on-lending of the proceeds of the ADB loan.

c  Access and safety features to be identified from the consultations that will be held with elderly people, women, and 
people with mobility impairments (as part of the gender action plan's implementation).  
d  Target may be adjusted based on the results of the survey and the assessment that will be undertaken among the 
women in the communities (done as part of the approved technical assistance gender subproject).
